introduction.content: The concept of modularity is widely used in a plethora of scientific and engineering disciplines [1] . Modularity divides structures or systems into subunits, that can be independently addressed and changed, without affecting the rest of the structure or system. Subunits may even be reusable for different structures or systems. This allows for low-effort, cost-effective assembly of, e.g. buildings [2] , hardware (through standardization of subparts), machine code (also: object-oriented programming) or genetic code [3] . In nature, well-defined subunits of only a few nm in size [4] assemble into higher-order structures [5] , [6] with sizes ranging from a few hundred nanometers (nm) to several micrometers (µm). As synthetic biology progresses, researchers aim to mimic such structures, both on a molecular and on a cellular level. Therefore, the need for modular building blocks capable of controllably assembling and disassembling into and from higher-order structures on biologically relevant time scales has become more urgent. Structural DNA nanotechnology has become a widely used construction approach in synthetic biology. Especially the DNA origami [7] technique, where a long, circular scaffold strand, extracted from the M13mp18 bacteriophage, is folded into any desired 2D or 3D shape using short synthetic staple strands, presents an indispensable tool for nanoscale engineering. DNA origami nanostructures (DONs) ranging from just a few nm to over a hundred nm can be easily designed and synthesized, with freely available CAD software such as caDNAno [8] . To date a large variety of DONs have been published, ranging from the simplest 2D structures [7] to functional DNA origami motors [9] . A very attractive feature of DONs is their complete addressability for guest molecule placement with base pair (bp) precision, enabling e.g. the formation of fluorescent nanorulers [10] , plasmonic nanosensors [11] , [12] , nm-sized force sensors [13] , [14] , or to study complex biological questions [15] , [16] , [17] . Despite all of these advantages, a bottleneck in DON design is the overall final size limit, determined by the scaffold strand (the M13mp18 genome is made up of 7249 bases). Although different insertions have led to scaffold sizes of close to 9000 bases, the overall size increase in 3D DONs is marginal. Therefore, a variety of different strategies have been reported to increase DON sizes. These include the use of a lambda/M13 hybrid phage as a scaffold source [18] , the development of orthogonal scaffold strands [19] , the use of unscaffolded structures [20] , [21] , [22] , origami slats [23] , [24] , or hierarchical assembly into finite [25] , [26] or periodic [26] , [27] , [28] structures. Each of these methods has at least one major drawback: With the lambda/M13 hybrid phage, synthesis of scaffolds larger than 50 000 bases [18] , equivalent to ~six regular origami was achieved. A similar size was achieved with superstructures from orthogonal scaffolds, reaching sizes equivalent to five regular origami. However, both approaches have similar bottlenecks: Firstly, the effort for scaffold production is increased tremendously and secondly, the unique scaffold sequence requires the same amount of unique staples to be designed and synthesized individually, increasing effort and monetary cost proportionally to superstructure size. The latter problem also affects unscaffolded nanostructures employing single-stranded tile (SST) assembly, where every ssDNA tile needs to be designed and synthesized individually. Nonetheless, using 10,000 unique ssDNA tiles, superstructures in the Gigadalton (GDa) scale have been constructed [22] . The largest superstructures reported to date were constructed using so-called DNA origami slats [24] , through connection of several long 6 or 12 helix bundles (HBs) via well-positioned, complementary ssDNA handles. These structures reached several µm and GDa in size and their synthesis is comparably cost effective. However, assembly is so far limited to planar 2D structures with low degrees of complexity in assembly. Yet it is the most efficient strategy reported to date for these kinds of large, flat and fully addressable superstructures. Another approach is the construction of superstructures with ssDNA connectors [29] , [30] , [31] , [32] . With this approach, different 3D shapes of superstructures can be constructed, but each connection requires many unique ssDNA connectors, making it susceptible to unwanted interactions and incomplete connections. GDa sizes can also be reached through hierarchical assembly, where successively larger structures are assembled in multiple subsequent steps. This approach has led to structures measuring 0.5 µm (2D), depicting a μm-sized image of the Mona Lisa [33] , while 3D structures could reach up to the GDa scale [25] . The high structural control and potential size make it an excellent approach for the formation of superstructures. Nevertheless, design and construction are faced with different challenges. For the hierarchical assembly of superstructures, connectivity always faces one of two problems: On the one hand, assemblies of self-complementary DONs lead to repetitive, homomultimeric finite [25] or periodic [26] , [27] superstructures. This approach is simple and cost-effective, as in principle only one type of monomer is required. However, it has the great disadvantage of an overall loss of structural control of the superstructure beyond the repetitive subunit, as only form and size of the subunit is controlled, yet superstructure formation occurs without control over the final structure. Consequently, it is impossible to controllably retain the site-specific addressability of the structure beyond the single monomer or subunit. On the other hand, assemblies made up of many different DONs, each complementary to one another, but not themselves, yield finite, heteromultimeric superstructures [9] , [19] . With this approach the structural control over the superstructure is high and the site-specific addressability is retained. However, the downsides are the requirement for a multitude of different DONs, leading to high design effort and increasing costs, proportional to superstructure size, and/or the need to be assembled in several steps, resulting in a tremendous decrease in overall yield. Therefore, currently, concepts combining both low cost and high structural versatility are missing. Such concepts could alleviate the issues associated with traditional hierarchical assembly and allow for the controlled assembly of large superstructures, or a multitude of orthogonal smaller structures, with retained site-specific addressability across the entire superstructure. In response to this challenge, we developed two methods for modularity and combined them in one structure, the moDON, a single modular DNA origami formed from one set of staples, but capable of folding into tens of thousands of different connection configurations. The large number of orthogonal connection sites allows us to increase the number of monomers in one-pot assemblies, circumventing the extraction and purification of intermediates as generally required in traditional hierarchical assembly. We were able to controllably assemble and disassemble manifolds of moDONs into large superstructures as well as smaller, more complex structures, in the xy- as well as in the z-plane. We engineered modularity into two different connection methods. The first method of modularity, in xy-direction, was created for shape-matching connection sites [25] , [26] . We achieved the multitude of connection sites by engineering a re-routable scaffold. Until now DNA origami was designed under the paradigm of creating one single, fixed scaffold routing for each structure. With this method alone, we were able to construct hundreds of individual moDON monomers with different shape-matching connection sites. The second method of modularity is a three-strand connection system in the z-direction. Here we engineered orthogonal binding sites with well-positioned, directional, and optimally sized handles, circumventing the problems occurring in other three-strand-systems, lacking rigidity, losing control over connection stoichiometry, and/or the impractical use of many different unique strands for each connection. The z-connections were engineered to be directional, non-branching, not self-passivating, removable, rigid, orthogonal, with a low number of duplexes per connection, and only made up of one single DNA sequence per connection site. Together with the xy-connections, this allowed for the construction of > 50 000 unique moDON monomers. We demonstrate the construction of arbitrary finite superstructures with connections in three dimensions. Additionally, we created periodic structures with monomeric and multimeric repetitive subunits reaching more than 1 GDa in size. Superstructures could be assembled in one-step reactions from monomers, without the need for purification and isolation of intermediate products, which is required in traditional hierarchical assembly. This greatly simplifies construction and simultaneously increases the overall yield. Further, we show that xy- and z-connections are fully orthogonal allowing for parallel and selective assembly and disassembly of each individual connection using different orthogonal triggers (see Figure S1 for overview). Finally, we show that the site-specific addressability of each monomer in the superstructure is fully retained by placing gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) at specific positions in the superstructures, demonstrating a highly controllable, efficient, and cost-effective strategy for the formation of large and orthogonal superstructures.

Concepts combining low cost and high structural versatility could retain site-specific addressability across the entire superstructure.

sentences.sentence: In response to this challenge, we developed two methods for modularity and combined them in one structure, the moDON, a single modular DNA origami formed from one set of staples, but capable of folding into tens of thousands of different connection configurations.
viewpoints: In response to the challenge of missing concepts in DNA origami nanostructures, two methods for modularity were developed.
The two methods for modularity were combined in one structure, the moDON.
moDON is a single modular DNA origami formed from one set of staples.
moDON is capable of folding into tens of thousands of different connection configurations.

sentences.sentence: The large number of orthogonal connection sites allows us to increase the number of monomers in one-pot assemblies, circumventing the extraction and purification of intermediates as generally required in traditional hierarchical assembly.
viewpoints: The large number of orthogonal connection sites allows increasing the number of monomers in one-pot assemblies.
The large number of orthogonal connection sites circumvents the extraction of intermediates as required in traditional hierarchical assembly.
The large number of orthogonal connection sites circumvents the purification of intermediates as required in traditional hierarchical assembly.

sentences.sentence: We were able to controllably assemble and disassemble manifolds of moDONs into large superstructures as well as smaller, more complex structures, in the xy- as well as in the z-plane.
viewpoints: Manifolds of moDONs were controllably assembled into large superstructures.
Manifolds of moDONs were controllably assembled into smaller, more complex structures.
Manifolds of moDONs were controllably assembled in the xy-plane.
Manifolds of moDONs were controllably assembled in the z-plane.
Manifolds of moDONs were controllably disassembled from large superstructures.
Manifolds of moDONs were controllably disassembled from smaller, more complex structures.

sentences.sentence: We engineered modularity into two different connection methods.
viewpoints: Modularity was engineered into two different connection methods.

sentences.sentence: The first method of modularity, in xy-direction, was created for shape-matching connection sites [25], [26].

25.1: Natural biomolecular assemblies often form by self-limiting hierarchical oligomerization of multiple subunits.
25.2: Molecular motors, enzymes, viruses, and subcellular structures are examples of natural biomolecular assemblies.
25.3: Large structures can assemble efficiently from a few components by combining hierarchical assembly and symmetry.
25.4: Viral capsids exemplify the strategy of using hierarchical assembly and symmetry to efficiently assemble large structures.
25.5: De novo protein design and RNA and DNA nanotechnology aim to mimic the capabilities of natural biomolecular assemblies.
25.6: The bottom-up construction of artificial structures with the dimensions and complexity of viruses and other subcellular components remains challenging.
25.7: Natural assembly principles can be combined with the methods of DNA origami.
25.8: Combining natural assembly principles with the methods of DNA origami can produce gigadalton-scale structures with controlled sizes.
25.9: DNA sequence information is used to encode the shapes of individual DNA origami building blocks.
25.10: The geometry and details of the interactions between DNA origami building blocks control their copy numbers in higher-order assemblies.
25.11: The geometry and details of the interactions between DNA origami building blocks control their positions in higher-order assemblies.
25.12: The geometry and details of the interactions between DNA origami building blocks control their orientations within higher-order assemblies.
25.13: The strategy is illustrated by creating planar rings of up to 350 nanometres in diameter.
25.14: The planar rings have atomic masses of up to 330 megadaltons.
25.15: The strategy is illustrated by creating micrometre-long, thick tubes commensurate in size to some bacilli.
25.16: The strategy is illustrated by creating three-dimensional polyhedral assemblies with sizes of up to 1.2 gigadaltons.
25.17: The three-dimensional polyhedral assemblies have diameters of up to 450 nanometres.
25.18: Efficient assembly is achieved with yields of up to 90 per cent.
25.19: Efficient assembly is achieved by using building blocks with validated structure.
25.20: Efficient assembly is achieved by using building blocks with sufficient rigidity.
25.21: Efficient assembly is achieved by accurate design with interaction motifs that ensure hierarchical assembly is self-limiting.
25.22: Efficient assembly is achieved by accurate design with interaction motifs that ensure hierarchical assembly can proceed in equilibrium.
25.23: Efficient assembly allows for error correction due to accurate design with interaction motifs.
25.24: The method enables the self-assembly of structures with sizes approaching that of viruses and cellular organelles.
25.25: The method can readily be used to create a range of other complex structures with well-defined sizes.
25.26: The creation of complex structures is facilitated by exploiting the modularity of DNA origami building blocks.
25.27: The creation of complex structures is facilitated by exploiting the high degree of addressability of DNA origami building blocks.

26.1: Discrete three-dimensional (3D) DNA components can specifically self-assemble in solution based on shape-complementarity.
26.2: Discrete three-dimensional (3D) DNA components can specifically self-assemble in solution without base pairing.
26.3: Homo- and heteromultimeric objects were produced using the principle of self-assembly based on shape-complementarity without base pairing.
26.4: Micrometer-scale one-stranded filaments were produced using the principle of self-assembly based on shape-complementarity without base pairing.
26.5: Micrometer-scale two-stranded filaments were produced using the principle of self-assembly based on shape-complementarity without base pairing.
26.6: Lattices were produced using the principle of self-assembly based on shape-complementarity without base pairing.
26.7: Reconfigurable devices, including an actuator, were produced using the principle of self-assembly based on shape-complementarity without base pairing.
26.8: Reconfigurable devices, including a switchable gear, were produced using the principle of self-assembly based on shape-complementarity without base pairing.
26.9: Reconfigurable devices, including an unfoldable nanobook, were produced using the principle of self-assembly based on shape-complementarity without base pairing.
26.10: Reconfigurable devices, including a nanorobot, were produced using the principle of self-assembly based on shape-complementarity without base pairing.
26.11: Multidomain assemblies were stabilized via short-ranged nucleobase stacking bonds.
26.12: Short-ranged nucleobase stacking bonds compete against electrostatic repulsion between components' interfaces in multidomain assemblies.
26.13: The balance between attractive and repulsive interactions can be finely controlled by global parameters such as cation concentration or temperature.
26.14: The conformation of assemblies can be finely controlled by global parameters such as cation concentration or temperature.
26.15: The balance between attractive and repulsive interactions can be controlled by an allosteric mechanism based on strand-displacement reactions.
26.16: The conformation of assemblies can be controlled by an allosteric mechanism based on strand-displacement reactions.

viewpoints: The first method of modularity was created for shape-matching connection sites in the xy-direction.

sentences.sentence: We achieved the multitude of connection sites by engineering a re-routable scaffold.
viewpoints: A multitude of connection sites was achieved by engineering a re-routable scaffold.

sentences.sentence: Until now DNA origami was designed under the paradigm of creating one single, fixed scaffold routing for each structure.
viewpoints: Until now, DNA origami was designed with the paradigm of creating one single, fixed scaffold routing for each structure.

sentences.sentence: With this method alone, we were able to construct hundreds of individual moDON monomers with different shape-matching connection sites.
viewpoints: The method of engineering a re-routable scaffold allowed the construction of hundreds of individual moDON monomers.
The method of engineering a re-routable scaffold allowed individual moDON monomers to have different shape-matching connection sites.

sentences.sentence: The second method of modularity is a three-strand connection system in the z-direction.
viewpoints: The second method of modularity is a three-strand connection system in the z-direction.

sentences.sentence: Here we engineered orthogonal binding sites with well-positioned, directional, and optimally sized handles, circumventing the problems occurring in other three-strand-systems, lacking rigidity, losing control over connection stoichiometry, and/or the impractical use of many different unique strands for each connection.
viewpoints: Orthogonal binding sites with well-positioned, directional, and optimally sized handles were engineered for the second method of modularity.
The second method of modularity circumvents the lack of rigidity in other three-strand systems.
The second method of modularity circumvents losing control over connection stoichiometry in other three-strand systems.
The second method of modularity circumvents the impractical use of many different unique strands for each connection in other three-strand systems.

sentences.sentence: The z-connections were engineered to be directional, non-branching, not self-passivating, removable, rigid, orthogonal, with a low number of duplexes per connection, and only made up of one single DNA sequence per connection site.
viewpoints: The z-connections were engineered to be directional.
The z-connections were engineered to be non-branching.
The z-connections were engineered to not be self-passivating.
The z-connections were engineered to be removable.
The z-connections were engineered to be rigid.
The z-connections were engineered to be orthogonal.
The z-connections were engineered to have a low number of duplexes per connection.
The z-connections were engineered to be made up of one single DNA sequence per connection site.

sentences.sentence: Together with the xy-connections, this allowed for the construction of > 50,000 unique moDON monomers.
viewpoints: The combination of xy-connections and z-connections allowed for the construction of over 50,000 unique moDON monomers.

sentences.sentence: We demonstrate the construction of arbitrary finite superstructures with connections in three dimensions.
viewpoints: The construction of arbitrary finite superstructures with connections in three dimensions was demonstrated.

sentences.sentence: Additionally, we created periodic structures with monomeric and multimeric repetitive subunits reaching more than 1 GDa in size.
viewpoints: Periodic structures with monomeric repetitive subunits were created.
Periodic structures with multimeric repetitive subunits were created.
Periodic structures created reached more than 1 Gigadalton in size.

sentences.sentence: Superstructures could be assembled in one-step reactions from monomers, without the need for purification and isolation of intermediate products, which is required in traditional hierarchical assembly.
viewpoints: Superstructures were assembled in one-step reactions from monomers.
The assembly of superstructures occurred without the need for purification of intermediate products.
The assembly of superstructures occurred without the need for isolation of intermediate products as required in traditional hierarchical assembly.

sentences.sentence: This greatly simplifies construction and simultaneously increases the overall yield.
viewpoints: The one-step assembly of superstructures greatly simplifies construction.
The one-step assembly of superstructures increases the overall yield.

sentences.sentence: Further, we show that xy- and z-connections are fully orthogonal allowing for parallel and selective assembly and disassembly of each individual connection using different orthogonal triggers (see Figure S1 for overview).
viewpoints: Xy-connections are fully orthogonal.
Z-connections are fully orthogonal.
The full orthogonality of xy- and z-connections allows for parallel assembly of each individual connection.
The full orthogonality of xy- and z-connections allows for parallel disassembly of each individual connection.
The full orthogonality of xy- and z-connections allows for selective assembly of each individual connection using different orthogonal triggers.
The full orthogonality of xy- and z-connections allows for selective disassembly of each individual connection using different orthogonal triggers.

sentences.sentence: Finally, we show that the site-specific addressability of each monomer in the superstructure is fully retained by placing gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) at specific positions in the superstructures, demonstrating a highly controllable, efficient, and cost-effective strategy for the formation of large and orthogonal superstructures.
viewpoints: The site-specific addressability of each monomer in the superstructure is fully retained.
Site-specific addressability was demonstrated by placing gold nanoparticles at specific positions in the superstructures.
The strategy for forming large and orthogonal superstructures is highly controllable.
The strategy for forming large and orthogonal superstructures is efficient.
The strategy for forming large and orthogonal superstructures is cost-effective.
